details.title: Introduction
details.details: HTML is the standard markup language for creating Web pages.

details.title: Elements
details.details: An HTML element is defined by a start tag, some content, and an end tag

details.title: Attributes
details.details: HTML attributes provide additional information about HTML elements.

details.title: Headings
details.details: HTML headings are titles or subtitles that you want to display on a webpage.

details.title: Paragraphs
details.details: A paragraph always starts on a new line, and is usually a block of text.

details.title: Styles
details.details: The HTML style attribute is used to add styles to an element, such as color, font, size, and more.

details.title: Colors
details.details: HTML colors are specified with predefined color names, or with RGB, HEX, HSL, RGBA, or HSLA values.

details.title: Css
details.details: CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets. CSS saves a lot of work. It can control the layout of multiple web pages all at once.

details.title: Links
details.details: Links are found in nearly all web pages. Links allow users to click their way from page to page.

details.title: Introduction
details.details: CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets. CSS is the language we use to style a Web page.

details.title: Selectors
details.details: A CSS selector selects the HTML element(s) you want to style.

details.title: Colors
details.details: Colors are specified using predefined color names, or RGB, HEX, HSL, RGBA, HSLA values.

details.title: Backgrounds
details.details: The CSS background properties are used to add background effects for elements.

details.title: Borders
details.details: The CSS border properties allow you to specify the style, width, and color of an element's border.

details.title: Margins
details.details: Margins are used to create space around elements, outside of any defined borders.

details.title: Padding
details.details: Padding is used to create space around an element's content, inside of any defined borders.

details.title: Tables
details.details: To specify table borders in CSS, use the border property. The example below specifies a solid border for <table>, <th>, and <td> elements:

details.title: Display
details.details: The display property is the most important CSS property for controlling layout.

details.title: Operators
details.details: There are different types of JavaScript operators: Arithmetic Operators, Assignment Operators, Comparison Operators, Logical Operators, Conditional Operators,Type Operators

details.title: Arithmetic
details.details: Arithmetic operators perform arithmetic on numbers (literals or variables).

details.title: Data Types
details.details: JavaScript variables can hold different data types: numbers, strings, objects and more:

details.title: Functions
details.details: A JavaScript function is a block of code designed to perform a particular task. A JavaScript function is executed when something invokes it (calls it).

details.title: Objects
details.details: Objects are variables too. But objects can contain many values.

details.title: Events
details.details: When JavaScript is used in HTML pages, JavaScript can 'react' on these events.

details.title: Strings
details.details: JavaScript strings are for storing and manipulating text.

details.title: Numbers
details.details: JavaScript has only one type of number. Numbers can be written with or without decimals.

details.title: Arrays
details.details: If you have a list of items (a list of car names, for example), storing the cars in single variables could look like this:

details.title: TailWind CSS
details.details: A utility-first CSS framework packed with classes like flex , pt-4 , text-center and rotate-90 that can be composed to build any design, directly in your markup
